abstract: Regulators may pave the way for a large group of banks, like JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, to leave the bailout program far earlier than many had envisioned.
snippet: Regulators may pave the way for a large group of banks, like JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, to leave the bailout program far earlier than many had envisioned.
lead_paragraph: Since the government pressed billions of dollars in taxpayer support on the nation’s banks, several strong institutions have been pushing to give it back. Now a few of them may get the go-ahead next week — a crucial step in disentangling themselves from Washington.

headline.main: Banks May Soon Get Nod to Leave the Bailout

abstract: JPMorgan Chase and American Express announced plans Monday to sell $5.5 billion of common stock, hoping to position themselves to quickly repay funds from the government’s bank bailout plan.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase and American Express announced plans Monday to sell $5.5 billion of common stock, hoping to position themselves to quickly repay funds from the government’s bank bailout plan.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and American Express announced plans Monday to sell a combined $5.5 billion of common stock, hoping to position themselves to quickly repay funds from the government’s bank bailout plan.

headline.main: TARP Driving JPMorgan and Amex to Share Sale

abstract: Following on the heels of JPMorgan Chase and American Express, Morgan Stanley said it will sell $2.2 billion of stock in an offering of approximately 80.2 million shares at $27.44 a share, freeing the brokerage firm to repay the the government’s Troubled Asset Relief Program.
snippet: Following on the heels of JPMorgan Chase and American Express, Morgan Stanley said it will sell $2.2 billion of stock in an offering of approximately 80.2 million shares at $27.44 a share, freeing the brokerage firm to repay the the government’s T...

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Raises $2.2 Billion to Repay TARP
